title: INTERSPEECH_2008_20_abs

sentences.text: In the study of expressive speech communication , it is commonly accepted that the emotion perceived by the listener is a good approximation of the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker .
This paper analyzes the validity of this assumption by comparing the mismatches between the assessments made by na ¨ ıve listeners and by the speakers that generated the data .
The analysis is based on the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions .
Therefore , self-assessments will be closer to the intended emotions .
Using the IEMOCAP database , discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments evaluated by the actors and na ¨ ıve listeners are compared .
The results indicate that there is a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion .
The speakers in the database assigned their own emotions to more specific emotional categories , which led to more extreme values in the activation-valence space .

summary: In the study of expressive speech communication , it is commonly accepted that the emotion perceived by the listener is a good approximation of the intended emotion conveyed by the speaker . This paper analyzes the validity of this assumption by comparing the mismatches between the assessments made by na ¨ ıve listeners and by the speakers that generated the data . The analysis is based on the hypothesis that people are better decoders of their own emotions . Therefore , self-assessments will be closer to the intended emotions . Using the IEMOCAP database , discrete -LRB- categorical -RRB- and continuous -LRB- attribute -RRB- emotional assessments evaluated by the actors and na ¨ ıve listeners are compared . The results indicate that there is a mismatch between the expression and perception of emotion . The speakers in the database assigned their own emotions to more specific emotional categories , which led to more extreme values in the activation-valence space .

Predicate-is_a_good_approximation_of.label: is a good approximation of
Predicate-is_a_good_approximation_of.description: This predicate indicates that there exists a close resemblance or similarity between two entities, concepts, or qualities. It suggests that one entity (the subject) is closely related to another (the object), with the degree of closeness being characterized as 'good'. The relationship established by this predicate implies an attempt at capturing or conveying the essence, nature, or characteristics of the object through the subject.

Predicate-analyzes.label: analyzes
Predicate-analyzes.description: To analyze something means to examine or investigate it in order to understand its underlying structure, properties, or relationships. The subject performs an intellectual process on the object, seeking to uncover insights, identify patterns, or evaluate its validity.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates that the subject's existence or validity relies on or is grounded in the object. It suggests a causal relationship where the subject's meaning, truth, or relevance are derived from or dependent upon the object.

Predicate-are_better_decoders_of_their_o.label: are better decoders of their own
Predicate-are_better_decoders_of_their_o.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a unique ability to understand or interpret its own object in a more accurate or effective manner than others. It suggests a high level of self-awareness, introspection, and comprehension.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: Indicates that the subject relies on or derives its foundation from the object. This predicate suggests a causal relationship between the two, implying that the subject's existence, validity, or meaning is grounded in the information, principles, or assumptions provided by the object.

Predicate-will_be_closer_to.label: will be closer to
Predicate-will_be_closer_to.description: Indicates a future state where the subject (e.g., self-assessments) has a more intimate or direct relationship with the object (e.g., intended emotions), suggesting an increased understanding, alignment, or proximity between them.

Predicate-assigned_their_own_emotions_to.label: assigned their own emotions to more specific emotional categories
Predicate-assigned_their_own_emotions_to.description: This predicate describes a process where the subject (e.g. individuals or groups) categorize and organize their personal emotions into distinct, more nuanced categories, effectively creating a personalized emotional framework.

Predicate-assigned.label: assigned
Predicate-assigned.description: The predicate 'assigned' indicates a relationship where the subject takes control or responsibility for allocating, designating, or attributing something to another entity (the object). This can imply a sense of authority, classification, or categorization.

Predicate-led_to.label: led to
Predicate-led_to.description: Indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the action or state described by the subject has resulted in the outcome or consequence represented by the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is related to another more general or overarching concept, which is represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the subject has a higher-level category or classification within a hierarchical structure.
